text: oh hi everyone anthony howtano here ow
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review
of this new king gizzard and the lizard
wizard album butterfly
3000. yes this is the newest full-length
lp
from ever-prolific and versatile
australian rock band king gizzard and
the lizard wizard who recently came out
with a one-two punch
of micro-tonal albums kg and
lw now these two records in my opinion
were not bad but not some of king
gizzard's best either
frankly i was pretty excited to hear
them move on to
another concept another idea as the band
always seems to be cooking up something
new
and on butterfly 3000 it seems like the
group is leaning a bit
on analog synths and electronics this
time around which is a really exciting
prospect to me personally considering
that one of my favorite king gizzard
songs of all time
is the closer to their environmentalist
opus fishing for fishies
of course i'm talking about the track
cyboogie
which is a track that has a decidedly
synthetic sound to it i truly think that
going electronic could
open king gizzard up into a whole new
world of
sonic mayhem and if the band is known
for anything it's their creative
treatment of
sound so i went into butterfly 3000
expecting
big things hoping just for a great lp
a new direction but um sadly i don't
think this record
is the revolutionary change in timbre or
concept
that i thought it would or could be nor
does this record come across
as distinct as king gizzard's records
typically do in the greater music
landscape
so what am i getting at when i say that
well synths and electronics do play a
pretty primary role on butterfly 3000
but only in the most basic way i think a
lead instrument can
when it comes to king gizzard's backing
instrumentation or their songwriting
style
little to nothing has changed on
butterfly 3000. maybe the vocals are
pushed a little bit more into falsetto
range
on a handful of tracks and again those
analog synth leads are there in your
face flying at the listener from every
direction but
aside from just merely using the synth
as a lead instrument
i'm surprised the band didn't dig into
this a little bit deeper as
butterfly 3000 to me sounds like mere
window dressing more than a new approach
which yes is slightly disappointing but
not necessary for a great record after
all if the
songs are great ultimately that i think
is what matters most
but on top of it i don't think this lp
showcases the band's best
songwriting chops either like not only
are the lead melodies of the intro track
yours pretty forgettable but
the song ultimately sounds like what
would happen if tame impalas kevin
parker
was going through some kind of like
prague synth or krautrock phase
then moving on to the track shanghai we
see the band playing with some
melodies that sound like they're coming
from the far east which
isn't necessarily a bad thing depending
on how it's applied but
in this particular case the melodies on
this one run
like i don't know just some tacky
exoticism it feels more gimmicky
than in depth the song dreams does have
one of the stronger and cuter
melodies on the entire lp but the band
does kind of run it into the ground with
one of the most one note structures here
the following blue morpho showcases a
similarly disappointing lack of
progression
some wonderfully eerie vocal leads as
well as a chord progression that kind of
resembles that of radiohead's pyramid
song
there's a cool rush of instrumentation
that hits right after the intro but
after that point the entire thing kind
of goes downhill from there
fizzling out on a non-ending and i can
foresee arguments in the comments about
how all the songs on the record segway
into each other
sometimes even calling back to other
points on the record melodically like in
the case of interior
people which is true king gizzard does
usually take care to make sure their
albums run like very holistic
experiences and
maybe to a degree i'm taking that for
granted however it's still the case that
on their best
lps as songs are flowing into each other
each track still does kind of stand on
its own merits individually as just a
good song which i just don't think is
the case for the bulk of the material
here the first tracks in this track list
that really
caught me off guard were easily interior
people and especially catching smoke
whose groove is absolutely insane
thumps so hard with some hefty bass plus
if i'm reading this correctly there are
a lot of lyrics about these
various drug induced fantasies on the
track that are pretty funny but then
when it comes to the final leg of this
lp
i gotta say i'm also not very impressed
there's the incredibly lackluster
singing on 2.02 killer year
there's also the zany and colorful black
hot soup whose angular layers of
guitars and vocals i have a difficult
time placing
on this record especially with the
synths not really playing a lead role on
this one now i will give it to the band
they kind of went all
out on the layering with the track you
love this is certainly one of the most
vibrant and exciting songs
on the entire lp this track is just
dripping with gorgeous melodic layers
and effects and transitions nicely into
the very
short to the point title track which is
kind of like a peppy finish for the
entire thing
but ultimately i'm just kind of sitting
on the fence with this one i just think
it's merely
okay even the best moments this record
has to offer i think
pale very much in comparison to king
gizzard's discography highlights thus
far
i love the idea of this potential
direction but
the band just doesn't really go that far
down the road
to pull the full potential out of it if
butterfly 3000 is the sound of anything
i think it's just barely scratching the
surface
i'm feeling a strong five to a light six
on
this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head it's another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano king gizzard forever
